field_edited_text.value:
Planned Development

Private: A significant amount of private
investment has been committed to Canton.
This includes:

*General Motors - In 1981 General
Motors Corp. announced plans for a
major modernization and a 433,000-
square-foot expansion of its Broening
Highway Plant. Total investment in the
project was projected to exceed $500
million. This project was suspended for

-about a year, due to reduced auto

,sales. In September of 1982, GM
announced the modernization would
resume although at a reduced level of
$270 million. As part of this program,
GM has aquired 26 acres in the Hola-
bird Industrial Park from the City with
an option on an additional 24 acres.
The Holabird acreage has been used to
replace a parking lot displaced by the
plant’s expansion on its current site.

*Consolidation Coal Co. - This sub-
sidiary of Conoco Oil Co. acquired the
Canton Railroad, Cottman Ore Pier,
and 110 acres of associated land which
it has developed as a major coal export
facility with an initial capacity of 10
million tons per year. More than $100
million in improvements has included



to Baltimore by unit train, a system in
which an entire train is used to trans-
port a single product to one final
destination. Consolidation Coal Co.
opened the facility in October, 1983.

*Canton Railroad - Canton Develop-

ment Co., a venture capital firm based
in Florida, purchased the Canton Rail-
road from a subsidiary of Consolida-
tion Coal Co. in October of 1982. The
company plans to expand the railroad’s
rolling stock and is considering con-
struction of a new office building.

*Rukert Terminals, Inc. - This Baltimore-

based company is currently improving
its bulk terminal facilities on Pier 5
along Clinton street at a total cost of $7
million, including $1 million in Indus-
trial Development Revenue Bonds. The
improvements include construction of
several new buildings for bulk cargo

storage and reconstruction of a pier

after the completion of the 1-95, Fort
McHenry Tunnel in Canton.

*Apex Qil Co. - Through the acquisition

of the long vacant ASARCO copper
smelting plant on Eastbourne Avenue,
the Apex Qil Co. has increased its
acreage fivefold to over 50 acres.

Public: To support the considerable



1

tion in the Canton area. The express-
way will link the Canton and Locust
Point industrial areas, provide direct
access southwest to the Baltimore-
Washington corridor and northeast to
New York, and relieve truck traffic on
local residential streets north and west
of the Canton industrial area. The
expressway is currently completed to
Keith Avenue. Work on the final phase
of 1-95 in Canton, the Fort McHenry

Tunnel, expressway approaches, and a

toll facility is scheduled for completion
in 1985. In conjunction with work on
the expressway, several new access
routes are being built.

In addition, various local street
improvements are programmed in
Canton; the widening of Ponca Street,
reconstruction of Poncabird Pass and
Haven Street and the reconstruction
and widening of Clinton Street from
Boston Street to Leland Avenue.

*Holabird Industrial Park - On surplus

Army land the city is developing a 170-
acre industrial park. Streets and utilities
are being installed and sites are being
marketed for general purpose indus-
trial uses. When completed Holabird is
expected to provide 2,500-to-3,000
jobs. In 1982 the federal government
approved the City’s application for a
20-acre Foreign Trade Zone.
McCormick Properties was selected by
the City to develop and operate a 20-
acre Foreign Trade Zone located in the
northwest corner of the industrial park.

Among other benefits a Foreign Trade
Zone allows components from over-
seas to be assembled in this country at
a reduced import duty. This encour-
ages new industries to establish assem-
bly plants in the zone and provide new
jobs and property taxes in Baltimore.

*Canton Seagirt Marine Terminal -

Dredge spoil from the excavation for
the 1-95 Fort McHenry Tunnel has
been used to create 147 acres of new
waterfront land between the Sea Land
Service container terminal and the
Western Electric Co. The Maryland
Port Administration will develop the
site into the Port’s second largest con-
tainer terminal. It will include three
new 1,000 foot long berths and an
extension of the existing Sea Land
service berth. The MPA has estimated
in 1982 that it will cost $123 million to
develop the new terminal. This invest-
ment is expected to result in approxi-

private development activity, the City is in mately 380 permanent jobs.
the process of implementing several large-

scale public works projects. These include:

renovation of the pier, construction of
a storage facility for mixing different
grades of coal, and reorientation of the
rail yards to allow more efficient coal
delivery. To speed coal delivery
Consolidation Coal Co. will bring coal

*Expressway and street improvements -
Completion of Interstate 95 will offer a
dramatic improvement in transporta-



41
